I am not at all moved by this movie, not that I am coldblooded or have no sympathy on children die of Malaria, but the movie itself lacks of power to move me. For one, it is hard to like the mother. She completely ignored her child and her husband, and when she realized that her child was bullied, she abruptly brought him to Africa without her husband's agreement; and her lack of basic knowledge on a wide-spread disease in the destination country and delayed treatment led directly to her son's death. For two, perhaps a politically incorrect view, it was a tragedy that her and Martha's children were killed by the disease but the disease is very rare in the states. Why the hell should the US government spend a lot of tax money to prevent this disease? It is perfectly OK if she could raise and spend a lot of donated money or her own money if she is as rich as Bill on Malaria, but it is plain wrong to ask the government of US to spend tax money on it.

I thought the movie was wonderful, beautifully acted by all.  My one criticism is that the very reason of why malaria has become such a scourge in Africa is not included in the film.  Yes, mosquito nets are good, but better is DDT spraying, which for so long has been seen as a danger to our health.  I grew up in the tropics, 1940's, 1950's when solved the mosquito problem.  During mosquito season, we were subjected to areal spray from ground trucks that sprayed foliage and from the air by spray planes.  We never came inside during spraying, having grown up with it all of our lives and my family never seemed to suffer any adverse effects from it.  Millions have died since DDT was outlawed by the Environmental Protection Agency and worldwide, but most people are unaware of this.  So in this sense, I think the movie was sympathetic to the deaths by malaria, but did not address the cause and solution of it.

When I played this movie, I had absolutely no idea what it was about.  I only thought that the title was interesting.

So, having no idea what I was about to see, I was shocked by this movie.

There should have been more about Martha's relationship with her son, Ben.
There was a lot more about Mary and her son George.

These two women with sons, one in England and one in America, meet by chance in Africa by the middle of the movie.

The movie started out very slow, way too sugary sweet, and then suddenly changed directions so that it felt like I suddenly was watching a different movie, turning full of sadness and anger.

SPOILER ALERT..

The scenes between Mary and George in Africa were too sugary sweet to the point of annoying. I wondered if he was being bullied in school because she babied him so much.

I was shocked to see George die so suddenly.  I looked up malaria on Google, and all of the symptoms that were shown in the movie, although short and quick, were true.  Mary allowed her son to be sick for three days before getting him to the hospital because she thought that he had the flu.  If she had researched African diseases before taking George to Africa, then she would have recognized his symptoms, and she could have taken him to the hospital sooner and possibly saved his life. Or, if she had dealt with the bullying situation at home, then her son never would have been at risk for malaria in the first place. She taught her son that the solution to a problem is to run away and escape it.  She was also escaping dealing with the problems in her marriage, which made no sense, by leaving her husband.

I was also shocked that, after George died, Mary wanted to go back to Africa again. She left her husband a second time, showing no interest in his grief, or trying to deal with their grief together as a couple. The husband actually felt the need to text message his wife on her cell phone, when they are home in the house together, saying that it was his son also, instead of talking directly to her because their communication was so poor.  That was a pathetic scene. I was shocked that the husband, in his grief, never screamed at his wife to blame her for the child's death, which I was expecting.

I was also shocked that neither Mary nor Martha were concerned about getting malaria themselves.
Both Mary and Martha had unhappy marriages that they should have stayed home to deal with.
Both of them left their husbands home alone to deal with their grief alone, as if the husbands were unimportant and all that mattered was the sons who were gone.

There should have been more story about Ben.
There was a lot about George, but not enough about Ben.

The scene where Mary burst into the classroom to shout at the two little boys also shocked me. Those two boys were obviously laughing on the inside, knowing that this lady could not hurt them. She only made it worse for her son, making him look like a mama's boy in front of the entire class. If she had kept him in school, George definitely would have been bullied even more for what she did. And, if he had lived, the bullying would have been worse than ever if he returned to that school after a long vacation, which was obviously an escape from the bullying, making George look even more like a mama's boy.  I couldn't believe that the school and the two boys' parents didn't go after Mary for that inappropriate move.  Did Mary really expect that the boys were going to stop bullying her son simply because she shouted at them?

And, of course, I was shocked when I looked up malaria on Google. I had no idea about any of it.

Mary's speech was very important, but Martha's speech was more powerful by making it all feel so real with pictures instead of numbers.

The acting was fine. But the story presents itself as a humanitarian tale, intended to awaken your conscience to the plight of the hundreds of thousands of kids who die every year from malaria -- and it's fundamentally dishonest. The movie offers mosquito nets as a solution, and anyone who has used them in a tropical climate, as I have, will tell you that they aren't the answer. Not only do they develop tiny holes that will admit mosquitoes (as happens in the movie), but if you roll over in your sleep so that part of your body touches the net, they will bite you right through the net.

The fact of the matter is that malaria had been essentially wiped out worldwide in the 1960s, not by mosquito nets, but by the pesticide DDT. Then came the propaganda campaign against its use, one of the first hoaxes of its kind. DDT use was either banned, or so strongly discouraged by the US,that its use was discontinued in countries all over the world. It has been estimated that campaign against DDT resulted in the deaths of 20 million children. We ought to dig up Rachel Carson and put her on trial.

Here, Curtis writes an Original HBO Movie about grieving and the emotional turmoil of two completely different women. One, a married American interior designer and the other a married English homemaker, caught in the same circumstance far beyond their control or belief.  Director Phillip Noyce brings a heart wrenching story with a point while developing Hilary Swank into a steadfast woman (Mary) behind a cause that must be near and dear to her own heart to have rendered such a superb performance. Martha (Brenda Blethyn) is equally shattered, feeling helpless and hopeless as she returns to the continent of Africa only to meet an inconsolable Mary.

These two mothers have lost their only children to Malaria, a preventable disease with the proper prior considerations.  Mary lost her young child, George (Lux Haney-Jardine), during a six-month homeschooling type sabbatical due to bullying at his school.  Martha's son, Ben (Sam Claflin), decided to take a teaching position there arriving at the same end as young George.  These two mothers cannot get their former lives back to anywhere near normal as the plight in Africa is ever looming.  With some aid from Mary's emotionally distant father (James Woods) being somewhat politically connected, these brave and tenacious women advance the cause of stopping malaria from sweeping Africa in epidemic proportions.  They find a rekindled spark in their personal lives and support from their husbands which they had held at a distance in their intense grief. Watching the direction that Mary and Martha take towards this humanitarian crisis is quite powerful in many parts, one being the speech that Mary gives to procure more funding for the cause.  Simply amazing ...

In this film, the mothers did not head straight in with all of the knowledge of malaria and being bent on changing it.  These two are struggling so deeply to find their way back from the grief of their tragedies which are gripping them.  This being the body of the movie.  The world horribly stretched out and struck them, now they are left to find a reason to give their particular situation a purpose - and a reason for changing it.  The script is powerful and emotionally charged but also delicately written in this direction and I could definitely appreciate its point of view.

Because the theme of the movie is so dark and difficult to watch, I went through tissues like everyone else surely will if you are the emotional type.  On the upbeat, the African views (Roberto De Angelis) were superlative.  The continent seems to show off for the camera quite easily.  The terrific and vastly different music (Philip Miller) was a joy to hear.  Give a listen to their take on Country/Western music (I loved the beauty of it).  The blending of the former along with the staunchly African beats was an enthusiastic twist and quite a treat, mainly in the first half of the story.  Then be ready if you are at all like me to have some tears falling from the terrific writing, direction and acting while showing what could possibly be done about this growing crisis.
